<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_dispatch:
```c
void metal_softirq_dispatch(void)
{
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < metal_softirq_num; i++) {
		struct metal_irq *irq;
		char is_pending = 1;

		if (atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i]) != 0 &&
		    atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
						   &is_pending, 0)) {
			irq = &metal_softirqs[i];
			(void)metal_irq_handle(irq,
					       i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
		}
	}
}
```
</target_code>

	void *arg; /**< Argument to pass to the interrupt handler */

Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not identify any explicit compiler language extensions in the provided code fragments. Rationale: 

- atomic_load and atomic_compare_exchange_strong are standard C11 <stdatomic.h> facilities, not vendor-specific extensions. Their use alone does not violate Rule 1.2. 
- Local variable declaration inside the for loop (int i; and struct metal_irq *irq; char is_pending = 1;) is standard C99/C11 behavior and not an extension. 
- The cast to (void) for the return of metal_irq_handle is standard C idiom. 
- The shown struct metal_irq snippet and the use of the macro METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE do not, by themselves, indicate a language extension; the macro expansion is not provided. A macro can expand to extension constructs, but without the macro definition or compiler-specific tokens (e.g. __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, __extension__, statement-expressions, asm labels, or other vendor keywords) there is no evidence of an extension to report. 

If you can provide the definitions/expansions of METAL_IRQ_CONTROLLER_DECLARE, the atomic object declarations (metal_softirq_enabled, metal_softirq_pending, etc.), or the compiler/toolchain documentation showing any nonstandard keywords used elsewhere, I can re-evaluate and report any actual language extensions found.
